In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Sure! Here's the `wrap_string` function in Julia that follows your requirements:

```julia
function wrap_string(text, text_width::Int = 10)
    lines = []
    current_line_length = 0

    for word in split(text)
        if current_line_length + length(word) > text_width
            push!(lines, join(current_line), '\n'))
            current_line_length = 0
        else
            current_line_length += length(word)
        end
    end

    if current_line_length > 0
        push!(lines, join(current_line), '\n'))
    end

    return lines
end

# Example usage:
text = "This is a test string with words that might exceed the text_width."
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text, text_width=8)
println(wrapped_text)
```

In this example, I've provided an example text and set `text_width` to 8 characters. The function will wrap the text accordingly and return a list of wrapped lines.
